# Logistic Regression

# What is **Logistic Regression**

- Logistic regression models the probabilities for classification problems with two possible outcomes. It’s an extension of the linear regression model for classification problems
- **Goal:** Attempts to model the response variable as **$P(Y=label | X=\theta)$**
    - Where $\theta$ represents the set of features

## **Types of Logistic Regression**

- Binary (Binomial) Classification (2 Classes)
- Multinomial Logistic Regression (Also known as One Vs All)
    - Logistic regression is designed for two-class problems, modelling the target using a binomial probability distribution function
    - The class labels are mapped to 1 for the positive class or outcome and 0 for the negative class or outcome. The fit model predicts the probability that an example belongs to class 1

## **Logistic Regression Assumptions**

1. Each predictor $*x_i*$ is linearly related to $logit(p_i)$ if all other predictors are held constant
2. Each outcome $*Y_i*$ is independent of the other outcomes

## **Why does it need to be used?**

- When using qualitative response variables rather than quantitative response variables for regression, it only makes sense IF **there is ordering among the response variables** (I.e. Predicting for impact of a drug --> illness, stroke, seizure)
    - Since there is no inherent ordering between these, it doesn't make sense to predict as a continuous variable
- **Rather than using a linear function to estimate probabilities for classification problems, we must use a function to scale outputs between 0 and 1:**
    - Any time a straight line is fit to a binary response that is coded as 0 or 1, in principle we can always predict p(x) < 0 or p(X) > 0 for some X values
- **The Logistic Function is used for Logistic Regression:** It’s an S-shaped curve that can take any real-valued number and map it into a value between 0 and 1, but never exactly at those limits
    - **However, since regression takes the form Y = mX + b, values can be between -**we need to transform the values to be between 0 and 1
        
        [data:image/png;base64,](data:image/png;base64,)
        
        - We use a link function to take the function Y = mX + b == logit function
            - Use the inverse logit function (to transform from X axis --> y axis

# **How it works**

- Input values are combined linearly using weights or coefficient values (Beta) to predict an output value
    - Like Linear Regression or GLM's
- **The transformation which takes place is merely just wrapping the linear regression equation into the logistic function to transform the output values**
- LogReg can use an iterative method like gradient descent to find the optimal values or a probabilistic method like Maximum Likelihood Estimation
- **Steps:**
    - The goal of this algorithm will be to update this theta with each iteration so that it can establish a relationship between the input features and the output label
    - Start with random $\theta$  values for each feature parameter and update after each iteration
    - Logistic Regression can use Gradient Descent or Optimization to reach its solution
    
    ![Untitled](Logistic%20Regression%20f4424e638eb74609bba43c408d25d82d/Untitled.png)
    

## Formula

$P(x) = \dfrac {e^{f(x)}} {1 + e^{f(x)}}$ where $f(x) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 + .... \beta_n$

### **Logit Transformation**

- This is used to transform our linear model into Logistic Regression so we can do classification
- $logit(p_i) = log_e (\dfrac {p_i} {1-p_i}) = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_1 + .... \beta_nx_n$
    - $\dfrac {p_x} {1-p_x} = log \space odds$
        - **Note:** $1-P(x)$ if $x = 1$ $\rightarrow P(x) == 0$
        - Odds very close to $0$ == very low probabilities
        - Odds very close to $\infty$ == very high probabilities
        - Reference for deriving:
            - [https://sebastiansauer.github.io/logistic-regr/](https://sebastiansauer.github.io/logistic-regr/)
            - [http://www.win-vector.com/blog/2011/09/the-simpler-derivation-of-logistic-regression/](http://www.win-vector.com/blog/2011/09/the-simpler-derivation-of-logistic-regression/)
- $ln(\dfrac {p_x} {1-p_x}) = f(x)$
    - In a logistic regression model, increasing $X$ by one unit changes the log odds by $β_1$
        - Alternatively, it multiplies the odds by $e^{\beta_n}$
            
            [data:image/png;base64,](data:image/png;base64,)
            
    - The log odds are linearly related to $X$
        - We do this so we can interpret the coefficient values
    - **LHS ==** log odds of the default class

### Coefficient Values:

- The amount that p(X) changes due to a one-unit change in X will depend on the current value of X, **since it is not linear**
    - **If $β_1$ is positive, then increasing X will increase the $p(x)$**
    - **If $β_1$ is negative, then increasing X will decrease the $p(x)$**

# Multinomial Logistic Regression

---

# **Estimating Coefficient Values**

---

## **Maximum Likelihood Estimation:**

- The parameter values are found such that they maximize the likelihood that the distribution described by the model produced the data that were actually observed
    - This is done by estimating μ and σ to determine the distribution of the random variable (RF)
    - For each parameter estimate, we solve for **β** which gives us the highest probability of seeing the data that we observed
- $f(x_1 = x1, x_2 = x2, .... x_n = xn \space | p)$
    - This specifies the probability distribution of X
    - p = p(x) --> Probability of x
    
- This is the joint probability of all values (observed from the sample) occur
    - Product of all the PDF functions
- **Generally, we do not know the true value of p**
    - **A framework for solving the problem of PDE**
- We want to know which curve was most likely responsible for creating the data points that we observed
    - Normal, Gamma, Exponential, etc. so we know which values are likely, and which are not
    - Ex: Normal Distribution takes 2 parameters: Mean, STD
        - Maximum likelihood estimation is a method that will find the values of μ and σ that result in the curve that best fits the data
- **The maximum likelihood estimates are the values for β that maximize the likelihood function**

- **Probability Density Estimation (PDE)**: Probability density is the relationship between observations and their probability
    - The overall shape of the probability density is referred to as a probability distribution, and the calculation of probabilities for specific outcomes of a random variable is performed by a probability density function
    - **Since the probability density function is unknown, we must approximate it using a method called (PDE)**
- **How it works: In order to get the MLE estimates:**
    1. Calculate the total probability of observing all of the data
        1. i.e. the joint probability distribution of all observed data points
    2. **Calculate the product of the marginal probabilities**
        1. total probability of observing all of the data is the product of observing each data point individually

# Hyperparameters

---

- **C: Inverse of Regularization Strength**
    - For small values of C, we increase the regularization strength which will create simple models which under-fit the data. For big values of C, we lower the power of regularization which implies the model is allowed to increase it's complexity, and therefore, overfit the data
- Penalty: L1, L2 or ElasticNet Regularization
- Solver: Algorithm to use in the optimization problem
    - See above for advantages or drawbacks to particular solvers
- L1 Ratio: ElasticNet mixing parameter, with 0 <= l1_ratio <= 1. Only used if penalty='elasticnet'. Setting l1_ratio=0 is equivalent to using penalty='l2', while setting l1_ratio=1 is equivalent to using penalty='l1'. For 0 < l1_ratio <1, the penalty is a combination of L1 and L2
    - sklearn documentation

# **Logistic Regression Solvers**:

- newtown-cg: A newton method. Newton methods use an exact Hessian matrix. It's slow for large datasets, because it computes the second derivatives
    - Only supports L2 regularization or None
- lbfgs: Stands for Limited-memory Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno. It approximates the second derivative matrix updates with gradient evaluations. It stores only the last few updates, so it saves memory. It isn't super fast with large data sets
    - Only supports L2 regularization or None
- liblinear: Library for Large Linear Classification. Uses a coordinate descent algorithm. Coordinate descent is based on minimizing a multivariate function by solving univariate optimization problems in a loop. In other words, it moves toward the minimum in one direction at a time
    - **Performs well in high-dimensionality**
    - **Drawbacks:**
        - It can get stuck, is unable to run in parallel, and can only solve multi-class logistic regression with one-vs.-rest
    - Supports L1 and L2 regularization
- sag: Stochastic Average Gradient descent. A variation of gradient descent and incremental aggregated gradient approaches that uses a random sample of previous gradient values. Fast for big datasets
    - Only supports L2 regularization or None
- saga: Extension of sag that also allows for L1 regularization. Should generally train faster than sag
    - Allows for ElasticNet Regularization

![Logistic%20Regression%20f4424e638eb74609bba43c408d25d82d/Untitled%201.png](Logistic%20Regression%20f4424e638eb74609bba43c408d25d82d/Untitled%201.png)

### Terms:

- **Odds** are a ratio of the probability of some event happening to the probability it not happening
    - Constrained between 0 and infinity
    - Large odds ratio == small probability and vice versa
